results.title: A Shocking affair
results.brief_description: An animated illustration of the safety rule: “Never touch plumbing and electrical fixtures at the same time.” In the film we see a young woman commit the fatal error of switching on an electric light while in her bath. After a fleeting glimpse of a gravestone with the inscription R.I.P., we see her in the next world where in her celestial tub she is about to repeat her mistake but remembers the consequences just in time.

results.title: A Ship is born
results.brief_description: Offers an impressionistic view of shipbuilding and the baptismal launching of a ship, showing the relationship between man and his work. Shows the gaiety of the launching day contrasted with the tension of the workers, whose last job is to knock out the timber stills and send the ship down to the water.

results.title: A Ship comes to Antwerp
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Swingler, British Petroleum and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Shows how the city of Antwerp is still dependent today on sea-borne traffic as it has been since the middle ages. Interwoven with the impression of the city is the arrival, docking, discharging, refuelling and departure of the freight ship ‘City of Karachi’. (Awards: Edinburgh Festival, 1953)

results.title: A Shared table with Stephanie Alexander
results.creator_credit: Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright, John Smith, ABC-TV (Australia), December Films and On the Boil Productions
results.brief_description: This tape is a compilation of the seven part series screened on ABC TV which followed renowned chef Stephanie Alexander on a culinary journey across different regions of Australia. At each destination Stephanie, with the assistance of fellow chef Elena Bonnici, prepares a meal from local produce. By doing so she reveals the diversity of local producers, and the ease with which these ingredients can be incorporated into a delicious meal.

results.title: A Set of slides
results.brief_description: Utilising over 400 photographs, the spirit of London of the 19th century is captured in dramatic style. Early modes of steam transport are shown, in particular the steam trains of the Underground. A familiar sight in the streets of London was also the horse-drawn vehicle. English people of the 19th century are also depicted at their jobs and in their leisure activities. Narrated by Anthony Quayle.

results.title: A Sense of theatre
results.creator_credit: Revel Guest and London Television Service
results.brief_description: Britain’s greatest currency in the world of arts is probably her playwrights. From the great revival of British drama in the 1950s has sprung a new generation of playwrights, differing widely in ideas and approach. A study of these playwrights; the way they began to write, the way they find their subjects and the way they live their lives is made.

results.title: A Sense of involvement
results.creator_credit: David Sims, David H. Fowler and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: The craft movement in New Zealand has established itself as strongly as in other countries. Using their different skills, potters, weavers, printmakers and sculptors are allied by a sense of involvement. Music and picture establish a mood which allows the audience to share their involvement.

results.title: A Sense of Direction
results.brief_description: A look at the sport of orientating. It starts by describing map-marking and how important accurate maps are. Shows maps being made for orienteering, based on grades of difficulty that orienteers are subjected to. It concludes with the maps being used in an actual race.

results.title: A Sense of community
results.creator_credit: Sarah Stein, Lee R. Bobker, Charles Stewart Mott Foundation and Vision Associates
results.brief_description: A portrait of community education in action. Examples of programs that take place throughout the community at all hours of the day and night are given, and the Community School Council is introduced. Other more complex programs are then shown with the emphasis on the impact on lives rather than on the content of the program.

results.title: A Sense of belonging
results.creator_credit: Margaret Thomson, Ronald H. Riley and R.H.R. Productions
results.brief_description: When Mrs Morgan, a dependent and inadequate housewife, loses her husband, her two children become neglected and unwanted, especially when their mother decides to marry again - to a useless and workshy man who has no feeling for them. They lose their sense of belonging, and the boy, Martin, becomes unstable and drifts into delinquency. The story of this family, over a period of years, is seen through the eyes of a Child-care Officer from the Children’s Department of the Local Authority, and through it, a picture of an extensive welfare service is built up.
